Description: Moisture spikes that occur without any nearby flow anomaly indicate water sources not related to the supply system, such as rain ingress, cleaning, or condensation.
short rationale: Identifies external/surface water by location; moderate sensitivity.

Description: Flow anomalies that do not produce elevated moisture at local sensors indicate abnormal but contained water use elsewhere, such as remote fixtures, tank filling, or good drainage.
short rationale: Contained usage characterization; low privacy impact.

Inference: Leak-like events without explicit leak sensor
Description: Large or prolonged flow anomalies followed by significant, sustained moisture increases in nearby sensors strongly indicate a leak even if no dedicated leak detector fired.
short rationale: Strong evidence of leaks with location/timing; high reconstruction risk.

Description: Flow anomalies followed only by small, short-lived moisture changes are likely heavy but contained usage, whereas anomalies followed by large or long-lived moisture spikes indicate leakage or overflow.
short rationale: Separates usage vs. leak by outcomes; moderate sensitivity.

Description: After a flow anomaly, the time it takes for moisture levels to return to baseline quantifies drainage and drying efficiency in that area.
short rationale: Recovery timing per area; moderate location/timeline exposure.

Description: Flow anomalies with small or delayed moisture increases at surface sensors indicate leaks in hidden spaces, such as inside walls, ceilings, or subfloors.
short rationale: Hidden leak inference with location context; high reconstruction sensitivity.

Description: When a flow anomaly is detected at an upstream level, the first moisture sensors to spike indicate the most likely physical leak location.
short rationale: Pinpoints origin via earliest moisture; high location specificity.

Description: The temporal order in which moisture sensors rise after a flow anomaly reveals the path water takes as it spreads across floors, rooms, or structural elements.
Repeated small flow anomalies that consistently precede slight moisture increases at the same zone form an early-warning pattern for developing micro-leaks.
short rationale: Precursors tied to zone/time; moderate-to-high sensitivity.

Description: If certain flow anomalies are known to cause leaks but never produce moisture changes at local sensors, moisture sensors in that zone are likely poorly placed or too sparse.
short rationale: Sensor placement diagnostic; moderate location exposure.

Inference: Correlating anomaly magnitude with wet footprint
Description: Larger flow anomalies that consistently produce wider or higher moisture footprints support a calibration between anomaly magnitude and expected physical spread of water.
short rationale: Calibration using incident outcomes; moderate detail.

Inference: Characterizing slow absorbing leaks vs. fast spills
Description: Flow anomalies with modest peaks followed by slowly rising, long-tail moisture indicate absorbing leaks, while anomalies causing sharp moisture spikes indicate fast surface spills or bursts.
short rationale: Classifies leak behavior; moderate incident specificity.

Description: Frequent flow anomaly alerts that rarely coincide with any noticeable moisture change suggest that flow thresholds are set too low or are reacting to benign fluctuations.
short rationale: Threshold tuning insight; low privacy impact.

Description: Flow anomalies that clearly represent large events yet only cause very small or no moisture excursions above threshold indicate that moisture alert thresholds may be too strict.
short rationale: Threshold tuning insight; low privacy impact.

Inference: Distinguishing supply-side issues from post-fixture spills
Description: Flow anomalies in the main line followed by widespread moisture increases suggest supply-side failures, while localized moisture after fixture-specific anomalies suggests overflow or spillage at that fixture.
short rationale: Cause differentiation with spatial spread; location-sensitive.

Inference: Temporal coupling strength between flow and moisture
Description: The typical time lag between a flow anomaly and the first moisture rise in a zone defines a flow-to-wetness coupling for that part of the system.
short rationale: Coupling metric per zone; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Persistent low-level dampness with intermittent flow anomalies
Description: Zones with low but persistent moisture and intermittent small flow anomalies indicate a chronic, low-rate leak rather than isolated accidents.
short rationale: Chronic leak signature with location/time; high sensitivity.

Description: Very large flow anomalies that consistently produce little or no moisture elevation at surrounding sensors imply that high flows are well-contained within pipes, drains, or designated channels.
short rationale: Identifies contained flow; low privacy risk.
